title: Introduction
body:
Learning Styles

Learners learn differently. As a Trainer, you need to understand this while preparing for the training session. This chapter will help you to accommodate your learners different learning needs and enable them to achieve their goals.

title: Preparing for the Training
body:
Emma has recently started her career as a Trainer. She has to deliver a training session on Hair Colouring Techniques (for GHD Hair Styling Techniques/for OPI Nail Techniques). To ensure that she conveys important information to the learners, Emma decided to prepare a presentation with the key points for each technique.

What is your opinion of Emma’s idea of creating a presentation to showcase each technique?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Collating the key points is a good idea and will help the learners retain the information.
Creating a visual presentation will appeal to creative minds.
Collating the key points alone will not help the learners.
Collating the key points is a good retention idea, but may not appeal to all the learners.

_feedback.correct: Well, collating key points is a good retention strategy to help the learners understand the dos and don’ts of the technique. However, Emma needs to present this information visually so that it will appeal to creative minds and also optimise the learning process for learners with different learning styles.

_partlyCorrect.final: Well, collating key points is a good retention strategy to help the learners understand the dos and don’ts of the technique. However, Emma needs to present this information visually so that it will appeal to creative minds and also optimise the learning process for learners with different learning styles.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
  • Describe the need to understand learning styles.
  • Explain the VAK model.
  • Explain the introvert and extrovert learning styles.
  • Demonstrate an engaging and inclusive workshop and seminar activities to manage different learning styles.

title: Understand Different Learning Styles
body:
Learners have different learning styles due to their natural or habitual pattern of acquiring and processing information in a learning situation.

We need to understand this to:
  • Maximise our own learning capability
  • Adjust the content to suit our participants’ learning styles
  • Optimise their learning opportunities
There are widely accepted theories recognised and used across different learning environments to tailor to the learners’ learning needs.

As a Trainer, you need to implement these to enhance the effectiveness of your training session.

title: Learning Style Modalities: VAK Model
body:
The simplest and most common way of identifying different learning styles is based on the senses. Commonly called the VAK model, this framework describes learners as Visual, Auditory or Kinaesthetic.

Here's how these learners learn.

Visual
Visual learners most effectively process visual information.

Auditory
Auditory learners understand best through hearing.

Kinaesthetic
Kinaesthetic/tactile learners learn through touch and movement

title: Learning Style Modalities: VAK Model
body: Depending on the research group, the outcome can vary, however generally the population outcome is:

_pinchZoomer._mobileInstructionText: Please Double tap to Zoom in the Image

title: Identify the Learning Style
body: Considering the different elements of our training, which learning style is going to suit which approach?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.
mobileInstruction: Choose an option from the dropdown list for each statement and tap Submit.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You have identified the correct learning style for the training elements.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Select the Correct Answer tab to view the correct mapping.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

Select the Correct Answer tab to view the correct mapping.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

_textSourceContent.source:
Below are the various modes suitable for each learning style.

Learning Style
Learning Mode
Visual
Pictures, videos, graphics, diagrams, charts, models
Auditory
Lecture, recording, storytelling, music, verbalisation, questioning
Kinaesthetic
Doing, practising, acting, role-play, scenarios, clay modelling

title: Additional Traits of the VAK Model
displayTitle: Additional Traits of the VAK Model
body: Here are the additional traits given by the different learning styles of the VAK model.
instruction: Flip each card to find out the traits of different learners.

_items.backBody:
• Are better able to remember images they have seen (charts, pictures)
  • Often talk using visually descriptive words – including colours and visual words, such as vision, see, show, look
  • Learn best through seeing
  • Learn best from visual displays
  • May ask: ‘How does this look to you?’

• Often talk to themselves
  • May move their lips and read loud
  • Often do better talking than writing
  • Learn best through lectures and discussions
  • May ask: ‘How does it sound to you?’

• Learn best with a hands-on approach
  • Chose to get up, touch and ‘do’ to enhance learning
  • May ask: ‘How does this feel to you?’

body: The graphic below presents the impact of the various teaching methods:

_pinchZoomer._mobileInstructionText: Please Double tap to Zoom in the Image

displayTitle: VAK Self-Quiz – Know Your Learning Style
title: VAK Self-Quiz – Know Your Learning Style
body: Read through the given situation and then score yourself from 1-5 (1 = least agree to 5 = entirely agree) for each statement -  choosing the one that most applies to you.
instruction: Select the score from the drop-down list for each statement. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.title: First Slide
headings: To operate a new equipment, you will:

_subItems.qText: Follow your nose and maybe use a compass

_items.title: Three Slide
headings: To cook a new dish, you will:

_subItems.qText: Call a friend for an explanation
Follow your instinct, tasting as you cook

_items.title: Four Slide
headings: To teach someone something, you will:

_subItems.qText: Demonstrate and let them have a go
I hear what you are saying

_items.title: Eight Slide
headings: If you receive faulty goods, you will:

_subItems.qText: Send or take it back to the shop

_items.title: nine Slide
headings: At your leisure time, what will you prefer:

_items.title: Twelth Slide
headings: If you have to choose a holiday, you will:

_items.title: Thirteenth Slide
headings: If you have to choose a new car, you will:

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
LEARNING STYLE
VISUAL
AUDITORY
KINAESTHETIC
Total Score
{{VISUAL}}
{{AUDITORY}}
{{KINAESTHETIC}}


The higher the score, the stronger your relative preferred learning style or styles. Remember that there are no right or wrong answers. Some learners have very strong preferences, even to the extent that they have little or no preference in one or two of the styles. Other learners may have more evenly balanced preferences, with no particularly strong style.

_incorrect.final:
LEARNING STYLE
VISUAL
AUDITORY
KINAESTHETIC
Total Score

{{AUDITORY}}
{{KINAESTHETIC}}


The higher the score, the stronger your relative preferred learning style or styles. Remember that there are no right or wrong answers. Some learners have very strong preferences, even to the extent that they have little or no preference in one or two of the styles. Other learners may have more evenly balanced preferences, with no particularly strong style.

_partlyCorrect.final:
LEARNING STYLE
VISUAL
AUDITORY
KINAESTHETIC
Total Score

{{AUDITORY}}
{{KINAESTHETIC}}


The higher the score, the stronger your relative preferred learning style or styles. Remember that there are no right or wrong answers. Some learners have very strong preferences, even to the extent that they have little or no preference in one or two of the styles. Other learners may have more evenly balanced preferences, with no particularly strong style.

_textSourceContent.source:
The questionnaire is designed to assist in the understanding of different learning styles. It is NOT a scientific research document and will have room for error.
This quiz is also available in the Resources section.

title: Guidelines to Train Learners with Different Learning Styles
displayTitle: Guidelines to Train Learners with Different Learning Styles
body: Here are some guidelines that you can consider when training participants with different learning styles.
instruction: Select the next arrow to reveal the tips.

second.body:
• Learn and practise different training techniques.
  • Separate different participants into different groups and give them an exercise to suit how they want to learn.
  • Be more aware of the group dynamics in learning styles and group the participants accordingly, when working on models.

title: Learning Styles: Introvert and Extrovert
body:
Another level of learning style modality depends on whether a person is an extrovert learner or an introvert learner. The differences between the learning styles primarily depend on their energy level.

Here's a comparison between an extrovert learner and an introvert learner.


Extrovert Learner

Introvert Learner
  • Extroverts are energised by social interactions.
  • Extroverts are typically thought to be outspoken, outgoing and predominately concerned with what's going on with the outer world.
  • Introverts find social engagements energetically taxing. So, after attending a group training or other social gathering, introverts need time alone to ‘recharge’.
  • Introverts, by contrast, are quiet, reflective and focused on the inner (mental) world.

_textSourceContent.source: However, extroverts/introverts are often seen as a kind of continuum, with people exhibiting a mix of introverted and extroverted tendencies – ‘ambiverts’ fall somewhere in the middle of this continuum.

displayTitle: Where Do You Fall on The Introvert-Extrovert Continuum?
title: Where Do You Fall on The Introvert-Extrovert Continuum?
instruction: Answer each statement True or False, choosing the one that applies to you more often than not. Select Submit once you have finished.

_subItems.qText: I prefer one-to-one conversations to group activities.
I often prefer to express myself in writing.
I seem to care about wealth, fame and status less than my peers.
I dislike small talk, but I enjoy talking in depth about topics that matter to me.
People tell me that I'm a good listener.
I am not a big risk-taker.
I enjoy work that allows me to ‘dive in’ with few interruptions.
I like to celebrate birthdays with few close friends or family members.
People describe me as ‘softly spoken’ or ‘mellow’.
I prefer not to show or discuss my work with others until it's finished.
I do my best work on my own.
I tend to think before I speak.
I feel drained after being out and about, even if I've enjoyed myself.
I often let calls go through to voicemail.
I prefer a weekend with absolutely nothing to do to one with too many things scheduled.
In classroom situations, I prefer lectures to seminars.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: The more often you answer True, the more introverted you are.

_incorrect.final: The more often you answer True, the more introverted you are.

_partlyCorrect.final: The more often you answer True, the more introverted you are.

_textSourceContent.source: This is an informal quiz, NOT a scientifically validated personality test. The questions were formulated based on characteristics of introversion often accepted by contemporary researchers.

title: Challenges Dealing with Introverts and Extroverts
displayTitle: Challenges Dealing with Introverts and Extroverts
body: Depending on your own preference, there is a definite challenge in managing the learning styles of introverts and extroverts together.
instruction: Select each icon to view the challenges.

back.body: Giving introverts sufficient time to ‘perfect’ their responses
Keeping both introverts and extroverts engaged
Maintaining a balance between self-activities and group-activities
Keeping the group focused on the task at hand

title: What’s your Perception?
body: Identify the learning style depicted in this picture.
instruction: Select the correct option. Select Submit once you have finished.

_feedback.correct:
When selecting the learning style for the picture, you might have selected it depending on your own style. There could have been a mix of both negative and positive perception.

Well, perceptions can be both negative and positive and relevant to our own styles. The learning in this is that there is no right or wrong. It is important for you to be aware of this, especially when conducting group exercises and the groups interactions/dynamics in understanding how it will impact your training session.

_incorrect.final:
When selecting the learning style for the picture, you might have selected it depending on your own style. There could have been a mix of both negative and positive perception.

Well, perceptions can be both negative and positive and relevant to our own styles. The learning in this is that there is no right or wrong. It is important for you to be aware of this, especially when conducting group exercises and the groups interactions/dynamics in understanding how it will impact your training session.

_partlyCorrect.final:
When selecting the learning style for the picture, you might have selected it depending on your own style. There could have been a mix of both negative and positive perception.

Well, perceptions can be both negative and positive and relevant to our own styles. The learning in this is that there is no right or wrong. It is important for you to be aware of this, especially when conducting group exercises and the groups interactions/dynamics in understanding how it will impact your training session.

title: Introvert vs Extrovert: The Perception
body:
POSITIVE PERCEPTIONS


EXTROVERT LEARNER

INTROVERT LEARNER
  • Lively and enthusiastic
  • Bringing great energy to interactions
  • Able to keep any conversation going
  • Skilled in social situations
  • Deep thinkers
  • Articulate in presenting their ideas
  • A calm and calming influence
  • Good listeners

NEGATIVE PERCEPTIONS


EXTROVERT LEARNER

INTROVERT LEARNER
  • Talking non-stop
  • Dominating the group
  • Frequently changing their minds
  • Social butterflies who can’t just sit down and do their job
  • Withholding important information
  • Uninvolved
  • Unfriendly
  • Good listeners
  • Making minimal contributions to team efforts

title: Map the Training Technique with the Learning Style
displayTitle: Map the Training Technique with the Learning Style
body:
Here’s an offline task that you need to perform.

Task: Identify the learning style for the given training techniques. Once completed, submit it to your Manager/Coach for evaluation and feedback.

Select here to download the task.

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • As a Trainer, you need to develop learner-centric training to ensure that both content and methods are appropriate for the learner. Also, understand that learners have a variety of learning styles and addressing the learning styles in the delivery of the training can maximise its effectiveness.
  • The two learning style modalities include the VAK Model and the Introvert and Extrovert learning style.
  • The VAK model describes learners as either visual, auditory and kinaesthetic, or a combination of these. Visual learners learn with the help of visuals, auditory learners learn best through hearing and kinaesthetic learners learn through touch and movement.
  • Extrovert and introvert learners have different personalities, depending on their energy levels. Introverts are concerned with what's going on in the outer world, whereas introverts are focused on the inner (mental) world. Introverts and extroverts can have a great impact on the group and this needs to be managed.
  • Identify the training techniques that work best for the learning style to ensure the effectiveness of your training session and make sure that the message gets through.

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, here are some tasks for you:
Using 'Your Task Sheet' in the Resources section, list additional challenges that you foresee dealing with introverts and extroverts.
Using 'Your Task Sheet' in the Resources section, prepare your checklist/guidelines stating how you will handle the challenges associated with the different learning styles.
Submit your tasks to your Manager for evaluation and feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.

title: Introduction
body:
Icebreakers

Jumping straight into a training session may feel like you are using your time effectively. However, if you do not get the group to ‘gel’ together, they will not work well together. Thus, it is essential to break the ice.

This chapter will guide you on conducting engaging ice-breaker activities and thus developing a collaborative learning environment.

title: Break the Balloon
body: Identify the terminologies that are associated with an icebreaker. Keep a watch on the timer. You have 30 seconds to complete your task.
instruction: Break the balloon by selecting the correct terminology. (Once you select the correct option then its color will change to green.)
_commonFeedback: This activity of identifying words must have grabbed your attention, as you were fully involved in it. Correct? Well, you need to set the mood properly before you begin when facilitating a training session.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
  • Explain the term icebreaker.
  • Explain the need for an icebreaker.
  • Explain situations suitable for using icebreakers.
  • List the benefits of different types of icebreakers.
  • Apply icebreakers for introducing participants, focusing on a topic and energising the group.
  • Identify icebreakers for the appropriate situations.

title: What is an Icebreaker?
body:
An icebreaker is an activity or a game that can be used to:
  • Welcome the participants and warm up their conversation.
  • Break down the barriers between participants.
  • Encourage self-disclosure, humour, respect for others and their opinions, thoughts and creativity.
In fact, icebreakers are interesting and engaging in just about any group situation. The trick is to know the best ones for a given situation.

title: Types of Icebreakers
body: Here are the three main types of icebreakers that can be used across a wide variety of situations.
instruction: Select each icon to learn the benefits.
mobileInstruction: Select each icon to learn the benefits.

_items.body:
When participants first come together, there can be a variety of mixed feelings, perceptions and attitudes.
The group need to get to know each other and break down barriers before they can start performing and working together.

This icebreaker is best to:
  • Meet and greet the participants
  • Introduce participants and warm up large groups

This icebreaker is used to introduce the topic of the training session or meeting. It might also generate laughter and conversation, but its clear purpose is to open up the topic of the session.

This icebreaker is best to:
  • Grab the attention of the participants
  • Remove any doubt and make the session clearer

When participants are strangers, these icebreakers help the participants to learn something about each other. This ensures that introductions and initial conversations take place.

It helps to:
  • Energise the group
  • Release tension
  • Bring enthusiasm to the participants
  • Encourage shy individuals to participate more fully

title: Map the Icebreakers with the Situation
displayTitle: Map the Icebreakers with the Situation
instruction: Select the icebreaker type for each situation. Select Submit once you have finished.
mobileInstruction: Choose an option from the dropdown list for each statement and tap Submit.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Here's the correct icebreaker type for each situation:

Situation

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Benefits of Different Types of Icebreakers
displayTitle: Benefits of Different Types of Icebreakers
instruction: Select each heading to learn the benefits.

_items.title: Icebreaker to introduce the group
_items.body:
Icebreakers to introduce the group provide the following benefits. They help to:
  • Familiarise complete strangers quickly
  • Create an open and non-threatening discussion – a good equaliser
  • Initiate a great conversational start
  • Ease any discomfort or unease at a session for the first time

_items.title: Icebreaker to introduce the topic
_items.body:
Icebreakers to introduce the topic provide the following benefits. They help to:
  • Look at the topic in a fresh way
  • Reframe the topic; creating clear open minds
  • Focus the group on the task at hand
  • Focus the participants on a new topic, moving from one subject to a different one

_items.title: Icebreaker for fun
_items.body:
Icebreakers for fun provide the following benefits. They help to:
  • Achieve good group dynamics or simply create a fun atmosphere
  • Release stress – pure fun is physically helpful. They provide an escape valve from tension from daily interactions
  • Generate laughter, which contributes to a genuinely relaxed meeting environment
  • Ensure active involvement – According to the Stress and Wellness Associates, people learn better when they are actively involved

title: When to Use an Icebreaker
body:
Not every occasion requires an icebreaker, so be selective.
Ask yourself these questions:
  • What value would an icebreaker add to this situation?
  • How will the group react to this icebreaker?
  • What would be the result if I didn`t use an icebreaker?
  • Do I need an icebreaker?
Addressing these questions will guide your decision process.

title: Icebreakers in Action
body:
Here are a selection of icebreaker activities for you to read through and implement to your training sessions to ensure maximum engagement with your learners.

Select each icon to view the icebreaker activities for each type.


Icebreaker to introduce the group

Icebreaker to introduce the topic

Icebreaker for fun

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • Icebreakers are valuable techniques to warm up the conversation in your training seminars or meetings, reinforce the topic of the session, and ensure that participants enjoy their interaction and the session.
  • The three types of icebreakers include:
    • Icebreaker to introduce the group
    • Icebreaker to introduce the topic
    • Icebreaker for fun
  • This training has helped you to understand:
    • What is an icebreaker
    • Why we need an icebreaker
    • Where we can use icebreakers
    • How to demonstrate the use of icebreakers for introducing participants, focusing on a topic and energising the group
    • Which icebreaker to use for what situation

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, here are a few tasks for you:
Conduct the icebreaker activities that you just looked at when you conduct your training session. Film it to let your Manager evaluate how well it was conducted.
Using 'Your Task Sheet' in the Resources section, identify one new icebreaker activity for each type of icebreaker and provide a rationale for its effectiveness. Present its objective/introduction, preparation required, method/execution steps and any additional information, if any, that is relevant to the icebreaker activity.
Submit your tasks to your Manager for evaluation and feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.

title: Introduction
body:
Moods and emotions can influence the learning. Happy, contented people learn, while frustrated, sad people don’t! One powerful emotion in a group can affect the others. Therefore, it’s important to manage the emotions of the entire training group.

People are human beings, and with that comes the challenge of managing them on a personal level. It is important for you to differentiate: you should not need to FIX participants. In your role as a Trainer, you should:
  • Keep an appropriate distance and focus on your role of ‘guide’
  • Listen to the flow, but try to keep within the scope of the training

This chapter will introduce you to some basic sense-checking techniques for understanding, managing and recognising the emotional dynamics of a group.

title: What Do These Emotions Communicate?
instruction: Select the correct emotion from each drop-down list and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Emotions can and will change during a training session, and therefore the face communicates a lot of emotion.
Here’s a description of each emotion.

Facial expressions are a form of non-verbal communication. The human face is very expressive as it conveys countless emotions without saying a word. It is the responsibility of you, as a Trainer to assess the moods of individuals or the groups – pre, during and post the training.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Emotions can and will change during a training session, and therefore the face communicates a lot of emotion.
Here’s a description of each emotion.

Facial expressions are a form of non-verbal communication. The human face is very expressive as it conveys countless emotions without saying a word. It is the responsibility of you, as a Trainer to assess the moods of individuals or the groups – pre, during and post the training.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

Emotions can and will change during a training session, and therefore the face communicates a lot of emotion.
Here’s a description of each emotion.

Facial expressions are a form of non-verbal communication. The human face is very expressive as it conveys countless emotions without saying a word. It is the responsibility of you, as a Trainer to assess the moods of individuals or the groups – pre, during and post the training.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Explain the need to check moods and emotions.
  • Apply sense-checking techniques.

title: Understanding Moods and Emotions
body:
You will come across different personalities: some prefer to stay passive, while others are enthusiastic enough to hijack the training agenda. Whatever the mood of the group or individual, it’s important to acknowledge it or they are likely to disengage.

Here are a few points to remember while handling such situations:
  • Acknowledge concerns, talk about them and put them to one side
  • Keep an appropriate distance and act as a guide
  • Listen to the flow, but try to restrict within the scope of the training

title: Impact of Emotions
body: In a training session, different emotions will have different implications on individuals and groups.
instruction: Select each card to reveal the impact of emotions.

_items.backBody:
• Strong emotions of individuals will powerfully influence the group (e.g. happy or sad).
  • The personal emotional energy of individuals will affect the way they engage with the subject, the Trainer and other participants.
  • Intense emotion relates to focused learning.

• Negative emotions will cause the participants to disengage (e.g. sad, confused, angry).
  • Positive emotions will help synchronise the group’s learning together.
  • Happy emotion relates to enjoyment. Therefore, giving surprises during training is a great way to engage the group.

_textSourceContent.source: In psychology – happiness, joy and desire are approach emotions. This state is one of increased dopamine levels, important for interest and learning.

title: How Will You Handle this Situation?
displayTitle: How Will You Handle this Situation?
body: In your training session, the participants are enthusiastic and having a lot of discussion. They are eager to gather additional information so the first two hours of the session have been quite slow.What will you do to ensure that the participants' energy remains high and that the session is also under your control in terms of time and content coverage?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Maintain the appropriate distance and act as a guide.
Restrict the discussion within the scope of the training.
Remind them of the training agenda.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: How to Deal with Moods and Emotions?
displayTitle: How to Deal with Moods and Emotions?
instruction: Select the arrow to read the guidelines to deal with moods and emotions.

second.body:
Guidelines to Deal with Moods and Emotions
  • Be sensitive but not afraid to address an individual if they are ‘taking over’ a session with their emotions.
  • Provide empathy without having to manage the emotion head on.
  • Don’t try to fix the participants; they are entitled to their feelings.
  • Recognise the positive and negative emotions so that the participants feel listened to.
  • Manage emotions, when required. If someone is overly excited, help them to focus, and if frustrated, find out the cause of the frustration and remove it.

title: Types of Sense-Checking Techniques
body: Some participants may find it difficult to express emotions up front in a verbal way. Using icons, images or analogies will allow them to communicate in a less personal way. The use of sense-checking techniques can be best used to deal with the emotions of such participants.
instruction: Select each icon to learn more about the three stages:
mobileInstruction: Select each icon to learn more about the three stages:

_items.title: Emotional icons
_items.body:
• Use different icons, such as the sun, clouds, thumbs, ticks, etc.
  • Limit the number of icons, for example, three good or bad or average.
  • Give the participants their own set of icons to show, when needed or asked for.

_items.title: Emotional associations
_items.body:
• Play with imagery; colours, shapes or landscapes.
  • Alternatively, focus the questions more so that the participants give a more specific response. For example, ask them to state, ‘In one word, what does the image say to you?’

_items.title: Analogies
_items.body:
• Localise your analogies depending on well-known analogies.
  • Alternatively, play with metaphors or use objects instead of images.

title: Sense-Checking Techniques
body:
Here are a few sense-checking techniques that you can conduct during your training session.

Select each icon to find out about the sense-checking techniques to evaluate emotions.


Emotional Icons

Emotional Associations

Analogies

title: Identify the Sense-Checking Technique
body:
Sara is conducting a training session. She wants to check the knowledge level of the group to find out who is feeling confident with the latest product initiative?
She uses the following options to gauge this:
  • I am fully confident and working with it
  • I am partially confident
  • I am not confident
Which sense-checking technique is Sara applying in her training?
instruction: Select the correct option. Select Submit once you have finished.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Sara is applying the Analogies sense-checking technique. Remember that if you plan to work in groups during the training session it is beneficial to mix high-knowledge (full glass) individuals with medium-knowledge (half glass) individuals within one group.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Sara is applying the Analogies sense-checking technique. Remember that if you plan to work in groups during the training session it is beneficial to mix high-knowledge (full glass) individuals with medium-knowledge (half glass) individuals within one group.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • Moods and emotions can affect the learning environment of the entire group or individuals within the group. Therefore, step back and try to understand, manage or recognise the emotions of the participants to avoid conflict, disengagement or hijacking of the training.
  • Sense-checking techniques provide an easy way to check the mood of a group. They also help to identify individual emotional energies and allow you to manage them within the group or individually.
  • The three different sense-checking techniques to evaluate emotions include:
    • Emotional icons
    • Emotional associations
    • Analogies
  • As a Trainer, you should be able to choose and apply sense checking to the appropriate situation. Also, adapt and create a sense-checking technique to best suit your workshop and learning activities, keeping it fresh for regular participants.

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, Here are a few tasks for you:
Conduct the sense-checking techniques that you just read about when you conduct your training session. Film it to let your Manager evaluate how well it was conducted.
Using 'Your Task Sheet' in the Resources section, create your own sense-checking technique to evaluate emotions. Present its title, objective, explanation, preparation required, method/execution steps and method, provide examples, if required.
Submit your task to your Manager for evaluation and feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.
